This study explores, for the first time, the influence of various C1 gases, such as methane (CH4), carbon dioxide (CO2), and biogas (CH4 + CO2), on catalytic pyrolysis of plastic waste (polypropylene) to evaluate their potential in producing aromatic hydrocarbons. Also, this study used the 0.5 wt%, 1 wt%, 3 wt%, and 5 wt% Ga-modified ZSM-5 catalyst and its reduction-oxidation processed catalysts owing to their promising catalytic properties. According to the results, the highest yield (39.5 wt%) of BTEX (benzene, toluene, xylene, and ethylbenzene) was achieved under CH4 over RO-GHZ(1) catalyst among all tested conditions. The reduction-oxidation process not only promotes a significant reduction of the Ga-size but also induces its diffusion inside the pore, compared to GHZ(1). This leads to the formation of highly active GaO+ ionic species, balancing the Lewis/Brönsted ratio, thereby accelerating the aromatization reaction. The effect of Ga loading on the RO-GHZ catalyst was also evaluated systematically, which showed a negative impact on the BTEX yield owing to the lowering in the concentration of active GaO+ species. A detailed catalyst characterization supports the experimental results well. Graphical Abstract This study investigates the impact of C1 gases on catalytic pyrolysis of polypropylene over Ga/ZSM-5 catalyst. The H2-O2 treated Ga/ZSM-5 catalyst under CH4 showed the highest BTEX yield (39.5 wt%) due to enhanced GaO+ formation. Keywords Polypropylene Pyrolysis Ga-loaded HZSM-5 Methane Reduction-oxidation 1 Introduction The increase in plastic production (e.g., polypropylene (PP) and demand is spontaneously leading to the accumulation of plastic waste, resulting in a significant environmental crisis. It is estimated that global plastic production will reach approximately 1.1 billion tons by 2050. According to the Environmental Protection Agency, so far, only 9% of plastic waste is recycled each year, and most waste plastic undergoes inadequate disposal practices, including ocean dumping, incineration, and landfilling, accounting for 79% of global plastic waste [1], resulting in significant environmental impacts [2]. Consequently, exploring innovative and eco-friendly recycling technologies for plastic waste is essential. Recently, advanced recycling techniques like chemical recycling through pyrolysis provide promising solutions for processing contaminated and mixed plastic waste by decomposing these complex materials into their fundamental components [3]. Catalytic pyrolysis has gained attention as a promising method for the chemical recycling of waste plastics to produce valuable aromatic hydrocarbons, such as benzene, toluene, ethylbenzene, and xylene (BTEX) [4]. On the other hand, another recycling method, the thermal cracking of long-chain molecules in plastic waste, is an energy-intensive, endothermic process that generates a wide range of waxy byproducts, thereby restricting its practical and industrial utility [5]. As a promising solution to overcome this challenge, catalysts can be employed to lower the activation energy needed for the process, thereby refining the product range and inhibiting wax formation [6]. Furthermore, catalysts improve the selectivity for aromatic compounds (e.g., BTEX) [7], thus enhancing the octane number (RON) of the resulting liquid product. Heterogeneous solid acid catalysts, especially zeolites, are favored for plastic waste pyrolysis due to their durability, low cost, and high supply stability. Their acidity and structural characteristics significantly influence the productivity of aromatic hydrocarbons [8]. Specifically, zeolites with Brönsted and Lewis acid sites facilitate cracking processes such as chain-end and β-scission. They also enhance the formation of naphthenes and aromatic compounds by driving reactions like isomerization, cyclization, Diels-Alder, and dehydrogenation [9]. Recently, many studies have incorporated metal oxides (e.g., Ga, Ni, and Co in oxide forms) into zeolite catalysts to adjust their acid sites, demonstrating enhanced activity for upgrading the products of plastic pyrolysis. Specifically, Ga-impregnated zeolites were found to be effective in producing aromatic compounds due to the dehydrogenation ability of Ga [10]. It was found that Ga/HZSM-5 achieved the highest selectivity for aromatic hydrocarbons at 39.3%, compared to 22.6% selectivity with the unmodified catalyst. Pyo et al. [11] studied the catalytic pyrolysis of PP over Ga/HZSM-5 using micro pyrolyzer-GC/MS. They reported that Ga/HZSM-5 produces more aromatic hydrocarbons than HZSM-5. Fu et al. [12] conducted the catalytic pyrolysis experiments of linear low-density polyethylene (LLDPE) using Ga-modified HZMS-5. They indicated that the selectivity to monocyclic aromatics increased from 70.35% (as using HZSM-5) to 94.02% with 7 wt% Ga-modified HZMS-5. On the other hand, some research is actively being conducted on enhancing the yield of aromatic compounds by co-feeding methane [13–16]. Pyrolysis in a methane atmosphere is particularly relevant in the context of plastic waste management, where it provides a pathway to convert non-recyclable plastics into valuable chemical feedstocks and fuels. This process aligns with circular economy principles by enabling the recovery of resources from waste materials. The methane-assisted pyrolysis process also has potential applications in upgrading bio-oils from biomass pyrolysis, enhancing the quality of biofuels, and producing high-value chemicals for the petrochemical industry. The continuous development of this technology, promises to further improve the efficiency, selectivity, and economic viability of pyrolysis processes. As global interest in sustainable and environmentally friendly technologies grows, pyrolysis in a methane atmosphere represents a significant step forward in the efficient conversion of waste into valuable products [17]. The co-feeding of plastics and methane has a positive impact, even in terms of overcoming methane’s energy limitations. Olefins and paraffin, which can be obtained by the thermal cracking of plastic, can facilitate methane activation by decreasing the thermodynamic barrier of methane in an aromatization reaction [18]. Compared to the reaction with only methane, the enthalpy of the formation of benzene substantially drops from 532.1 to 347.4 kJ/mol when ethane and propane are introduced into the methane feed [18]. Lee et al. [19] reported that the Gibbs free energy decreases from 243.0 to 10.5 kJ/mol when co-feeding with ethane and propane on the methane dehydroaromatization at the reaction temperature of 650 °C, and also indicated that the reaction becomes more favorable at lower temperatures. Additionally, a key factor in aromatization reactions under the methane atmosphere is the hydrogen-transfer reaction between the light hydrocarbons and methane [19], and it can be facilitated by GaO+ (gallyl ion), leading to an enhanced selectivity for aromatic hydrocarbons [20,21]. Song et al. [22] studied the co-aromatization of methane and propane over GaO y -supported mesoporous HZSM-5. They reported that the 2 wt% of gallium oxide, supported on mesoporous HZSM-5 with a Si/Al molar ratio of 20, showed the highest catalytic performance with an initial BTX yield of 14.2%. However, the use of excessive carbon sources such as CH4 can lead to issues with coke deposition on the zeolite catalysts. To solve this, many studies on the introduction of CO2 into the feed have been conducted to inhibit coke formation [23–25]. From this perspective, research on plastic pyrolysis in a biogas atmosphere is noteworthy. Biogas is produced from the anaerobic digestion of organic materials by microorganisms and is composed primarily of methane and CO2. Although significant research is underway to utilize biogas as a renewable fuel, a substantial amount of biogas remains unused and is often incinerated. This unused biogas has the potential to be utilized as a co-feed in the catalytic pyrolysis of plastic. Light hydrocarbons such as ethane and propane, generated during the decomposition of plastics, can enhance the co-aromatization reactivity of methane over Ga species. Consequently, methane from biogas could increase the yield of aromatic compounds in the plastic pyrolysis process, while CO2 could help reduce coke formation, thereby extending the catalyst’s lifespan. While extensive research has investigated the production of aromatics from catalytic pyrolysis of plastics in inert environments (e.g., N2 and He), there remains a significant gap in studies examining the generation of BTEX compounds in atmospheres of sustainable C1 gases. Therefore, this study investigates comprehensively the effects of C1-containing gases (CH4, biogas, and CO2) on the yield of aromatics during the simultaneous pyrolysis of waste plastics over Ga/ZSM-5 catalysts. Moreover, a systematic pathway was also proposed to reveal the role of the catalyst’s active sites and diverse C1 gas atmospheres toward BTEX production. This approach aims to explore the potential for converting waste resources into high-value aromatics and enhancing resource recycling with the suppression of catalyst coking. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials and catalyst preparation PP was obtained from a local company in South Korea. Also, ZSM-5 (Si/Al: 30) was purchased from Zeolyst. 1 wt% Ga/HZSM-5 was prepared via capillary impregnation (dry impregnation) method, using an aqueous solution of gallium(III) nitrate hydrate (Sigma Aldrich, 99.9%), where the content of Ga is adjusted to 1 wt%. The pristine ZSM-5 and Ga-impregnated ZSM-5 were calcined at 550 °C under an air atmosphere for 3 h. Those samples are denoted as HZ and GHZ(1), respectively. To enhance the dispersion of Ga species, the prepared GHZ(1) was thermally treated under a hydrogen atmosphere (50% H2 in N2 balance) at 500 °C for 3 h, and consequently calcined at 550 °C for 3 h under an air atmosphere. The reduction-oxidation treated samples were named RO-GHZ(x), where x indicates the Ga loading (0.5 wt%, 1 wt%, 3 wt%, and 5 wt%). The synthesized catalysts were characterized by nitrogen (N2) sorption measurement, X-ray diffraction (XRD), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), CO2-temperature programmed desorption (TPD), NH3-TPD, H2-temperature programmed reduction (TPR), pyridine Fourier transformed infrared (FT-IR), and transmission electron microscopy (TEM) analyses. The information about the procedures of these analyses is given in the Supplementary material (S1). 2.2 Pyrolysis experiments and data analysis The catalytic pyrolysis of PP was performed using a vertical two-part reactor system equipped with a gas flow indicator controller, temperature indicator controller, condenser, and gas sampling system, as shown in Fig. 1 . The reactor system was configured with 6 g of PP in the upper section for feed preparation and 2 g of various catalysts in the lower section for catalytic upgrading. Before the reaction, the electric heaters of feedstock and catalyst sections were preheated to 600 and 550 °C, respectively, under N2 gas flow (50 mL/min), which was injected to remove the air inside the reactor. When the target temperature was reached, the N2 gas flow was replaced with the desired pyrolysis media (CH4/N2/He: 40/5/55, CH4/CO2/N2/He: 40/26.5/5/28.5, CO2/N2: 95/5 in volume ratio) with a flow rate of 50 mL/min. After purging for 3 min, the electric heater of the top section was arranged to surround the feedstock reactor, providing the heat required for pyrolysis for 10 min. The outlet of the bottom reactor was connected to two condensers maintained at −20 °C using a chiller for the condensation and collection of oil. The generated gas passed through the condenser was then collected in a Tedlar bag connected to the end of the final condenser. The qualitative analysis of oil was carried out using gas chromatography/mass spectrometry (GC/MS, Agilent Technologies, 7890B/5975C) with a HP-5 column (30 m × 0.32 mm × 0.25 μm). The quantitative analysis of BTEX in the oil was performed using a GC/Flame Ionization detector (GC/FID). Gas products were analyzed by GC/TCD and GC/FID. Detailed analytical conditions are provided in the Supplementary material (S2). The yields of different products such as oil, coke, and gas were calculated by Eqs. (1)–(3) as follows. To calibrate and quantify BTEX yield, a 1 mol/L fluoranthene solution in ethyl acetate was used as an internal standard. A fixed amount of this solution was added to four known BTEX concentrations in ethyl acetate. These prepared standards were injected into a GC to create a calibration curve and determine the response factor (RF). The internal standard was then added to all samples, which were injected into the GC. Finally, the concentration of unknown samples was calculated using Eq. (4). (1) Oil yield ( wt % ) = weight of oil produced ( g ) weight of initial feedstock ( g ) × 100 (2) Coke yield ( wt % ) = weight loss of spent catalyst during oxidation ( g ) weight of initial feedstock ( g ) × 100 (3) Gas yield ( wt % ) = 100 - ( Oil + Coke ) (4) BTEX yield ( wt % ) = ( B + T + E + X ) amount in oil ( g ) feedstock ( g ) × 100 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization 3.1.1 N2 sorption analysis The results of the N2 sorption analysis of HZ, GHZ(1), RO-GHZ(1), RO-GHZ(3), and RO-GHZ(5) are demonstrated in T@able 1 including the BET surface area (S BET), micropore surface area (S Micro), external surface area (S External), pore volume, and micropore volume. The S External of GHZ(1) increased from 35 to 39 m2/g after Ga impregnation. However, S Micro and micropore volume decreased significantly, indicating partial blockage of micropores by the bulky Ga2O3 species. This suggests that the impregnated Ga species were primarily deposited on the external surface of the support while partially occluding the micropores. After the reduction-oxidation treatment of GHZ(1), the S BET, S Micro, and pore volume recovered significantly in RO-GHZ(1). This is attributed to the transformation of bulky Ga2O3 into smaller GaO+ species, which can migrate into the micropores of HZ during the reduction-oxidation process. According to Eqs. (5)–(7), the conversion of Ga2O3 with large size to GaO+ with small size occurs through a series of redox reactions. Initially, Ga2O3 is reduced to Ga2O, and then further oxidized to the more reactive GaO+, which exhibits higher Lewis acidity and improved catalytic properties due to their uniform dispersion within the zeolite’s pores. This transformation enhances catalytic efficiency by increasing reaction rates and improving selectivity during pyrolysis [26]. (5) Ga2O3 + 2H2 → Ga2O + 2H2O (6) Ga2O + 2Z-H+ → 2Z-Ga+ + H2O (7) 2Z-Ga+ + O2 → 2Z-GaO+ Nevertheless, compared to the RO-GHZ(3) and RO-GHZ(5) catalysts, the RO-GHZ(1) exhibited a more substantial recovery in surface properties, including the micropore surface area and micropore volume. This indicates that, for RO-GHZ(1), the majority of the bulky Ga2O3 species were successfully converted into smaller GaO+ particles and dispersed uniformly within the micropores. The higher gallium content in RO-GHZ(3) and RO-GHZ(5), however, limits the extent of Ga2O3’s transformation into GaO+. This limitation results in residual Ga2O3 on the outer surface, reducing the overall micropore utilization. In summary, the analysis demonstrates that the reduction-oxidation process significantly enhances the dispersion of Ga species within the zeolite framework for catalysts with moderate gallium loading, such as RO-GHZ(1). For higher Ga loadings, as in RO-GHZ(3) and RO-GHZ(5), a portion of the Ga2O3 species remains on the external surface, which constrains the full utilization of the catalyst’s microporous structure. 3.1.2 XPS analysis The XPS spectra of Ga 2p and Ga 3d for the Ga2O3 of GHZ and RO-GHZ(x) are shown in (Figs. 2(a) and (b) ), respectively. The peaks corresponding to Ga 2p 3/2, and Ga 3d for the GHZ(1) were observed at binding energies of 1118.7, and 20.7 eV, respectively [27]. The GaO+ species exhibited binding energies around 1119.51–1119.61 eV, and Ga2O3 displayed slightly lower binding energies (1118.61–1118.65 eV) [19]. Compared to GHZ, RO-GHZ(1) exhibited a significant decrease in the intensity of Ga2O3, along with an increase in their GaO+ species (1119.12 eV). Furthermore, the Ga 3d peak was not visible in the RO-GHZ(1). This suggests that the most of the bulk Ga2O3 on the surface of RO-GHZ(1) catalyst were converted into a small size of GaO+, and evenly dispersed within the catalyst’s pores during the reduction-oxidation process [28]. RO-GHZ(3) and RO-GHZ(5) also showed a increase of GaO+ species and slight decrease of Ga2O3 in the binding energy of the Ga 2p 3/2 peaks toward higher values than those of GHZ(1), which is attributed to the strong interaction between Ga and HZ. However, the high intensity of Ga2O3 peaks and the remaining Ga 3d peaks of RO-GHZ(3) and RO-GHZ(5) indicates Ga2O3 still exists on the outer surface of the catalysts and cannot be fully dispersed into the zeolite pores even after the reduction-oxidation treatment [28]. This phenomenon was observed as a gradual increase in peak intensity with the increasing amount of Ga. 3.1.3 H2-TPR analysis The H2-TPR profiles of the catalysts provide valuable insights into their reduction behavior, revealing an integration of four peaks that correspond to the reduction of specific Ga species. According to Fig. 3 , the reduction peaks of Ga with different oxidation states were observed at four different temperatures: (1) 300–400 °C corresponding to the reduction of Ga2O, (2) 550–620 °C corresponding to the reduction of highly dispersed Ga2O3, (3) 620–720 °C corresponding to the reduction of highly dispersed GaO+, and (4) > 720 °C corresponding to the reduction of bulk Ga2O3 [29–31]. In the TPR profile of R-GHZ(1) sample that was obtained by reducing the GHZ(1) sample at 500 °C, the first peak is more intense than other profiles, which is attributed to the high content of Ga2O species derived from the reduction of Ga2O3 during reduction process. Meanwhile, the fourth peak decreased significantly after the reduction process, indicating that bulk Ga2O3 species are re-dispersed to small Ga2O particles or small Ga2O3 particles during the reduction. In the case of RO-GHZ(1) sample that was obtained via subsequent oxidation of R-GHZ(1) at 550 °C, all three peaks corresponding to the reduction of Ga2O3 species and Ga2O decreased notably, but the peak for GaO+ increased slightly. Such changes of peak intensity can be ascribed to the generation of GaO+ species from Ga2O3 and Ga2O via the oxidation process. However, as the Ga content increases from 1 wt% to 3 wt% (or 5 wt%), the fourth peak is still apparently observed even after the reduction-oxidation process. This result means that some of Ga species were in GaO+ state, but the others still remained as bulk Ga2O3 phase mostly at the external surfaces of the zeolite particles after the reduction-oxidation process. The remaining bulk Ga2O3 in the Ga-content samples was also confirmed in TEM investigation. It is certain that the TPR results substantiate the present proposed mechanism on the transformation of Ga species during the reduction-oxidation process (see Eqs. (5)–(7). 3.1.4 XRD analysis The XRD patterns of HZ, GHZ(1), and RO-GHZ(1) were shown in Fig. 4 . The characteristic diffraction peaks of the HZSM-5 structure were in accordance with JCPDS (00-042-0024) [32] card data for all the catalysts, revealing the maintenance of the structure and crystallinity of HZSM-5 even after the metal impregnation and reduction-oxidation processes. Moreover, no extra peaks are evident in the Ga-modified HZ samples compared to the parent HZ, suggesting the high dispersion of Ga particles. The small amount of loaded metal, the position of Ga cations, and the substitution of some H+ with Ga may lead to overlapped peaks [33]. The intensity of peaks observed in RO-GHZ(1) was lower than that of GHZ(1) and HZ. This can be attributed to the role of reduction/re-oxidation, where Ga2O3 species are exchanged with GaO+ ions. Hence, the small-sized GaO+ ions can easily enter the inner pores of HZ and lead to lower-intensity peaks in RO-GHZ(x) catalysts. The intensity of XRD patterns for microporous materials is strongly influenced by the particles inside the microporous channel structure [33–35]. Additionally, the peak intensity of RO-GHZ(5) further decreased, indicating that the distributed Ga particles partially covers the HZSM-5 surface, thereby decreasing the intensity of X-ray reflections from the ZSM-5 crystal planes. 3.1.5 NH3-TPD analysis The NH3-TPD curves are shown in Fig. 5 , and the amount of acid sites in catalysts calculated from the TPD curves is summarized in T@able 2 . The peak in the 100 to 300 °C range represents the distribution of weak and moderate acid sites on the catalyst, while the amount of strong acid sites can be determined from the peak above 350 °C. The increase in the density of weak and moderate acid sites from 0.67 mmol/g in HZ to 0.673 mmol/g in GHZ(1) and the decrease of the density of the strong acid sites can be attributed to the interaction of Ga2O3 species with the HZ framework. Ga2O3 may interact with the aluminosilicate framework in a way that modifies existing acid sites to behave more like weak acid sites [26] . According to T@able 2, for RO-GHZ(1), the density of weak and medium acid sites increased, compared to GHZ(1) and HZ. GaO+ species are highly mobile and can be dispersed more uniformly within the proton sites (H+) of HZ zeolite. This increased dispersion is crucial for catalytic activity, as it provides a greater number of moderate and strong acid sites with enhanced accessibility for reactants, compared to GHZ(1). Moreover, among the RO-GHZ(x) series, RO-GHZ(1) showed the highest total amount of acid sites (0.961 mmol/g). This indicates that RO-GHZ(1) possesses a proper distribution of acidic sites. The increased weak and medium acid sites in the RO-GHZ(1) catalyst can be a valuable strategy for enhancing the catalytic performance in pyrolysis applications. By increasing the proportion of medium and weak acid sites, the stability of the catalyst can be improved [36]. Notably, strong acid sites promote the breaking of C–C bonds, while weak and moderate acid sites tend to dissociate hydrogen protons, which can promote hydrogen transfer and isomerization processes [37]. 3.1.6 Pyridine FT-IR analysis FT-IR spectra of catalysts with pyridine adsorption are represented in Fig. 6 , and the calculation of the ratio of Lewis acid sites (L) to Brönsted acid sites (B) is presented in T@able 3 . The bands at 1455 cm−1 observed in HZ and Ga-modified HZ catalysts correspond to the Lewis acid sites of the samples. Meanwhile, the adsorption band at 1545 cm−1 confirmed the presence of Brönsted acid sites. The peak at 1490 cm−1 is known as the combination of Lewis and Bronsted acid sites [38,39]. Also, the intensity of the peaks caused by L acid and B sites in all catalysts, especially the reduction/re-oxidation catalysts, remained almost unchanged, which shows the presence of strong Lewis acid and Brönsted acid sites on the catalyst surface. For the Ga-modified HZ catalysts, a higher Lewis/Brönsted ratio was observed compared to HZ. Additionally, RO-GHZ(1) exhibited an increased Lewis/Brönsted ratio compared to GHZ(1) after reduction-oxidation treatment, and this ratio progressively increased with higher amounts of gallium, reaching a maximum value of 0.764 in RO-GHZ(5). Therefore, an improved ratio of Lewis acid to Brönsted acid sites can be explained by the impregnation of Ga as an advantage in pyrolysis processes, allowing the catalyst to effectively catalyze a broader range of reactions, leading to improved selectivity and product yields [40,41]. Ga2O3 is known for having Lewis acidic properties because of the gallium ions in the +3-oxidation state. Notably, the Lewis acid sites arise from the ability of Ga3+ to accept electron pairs from Lewis bases. Furthermore, the transition from Ga2O3 species to GaO+ ions during the reduction-oxidation processes in the RO-GHZ(1) catalyst can increase the density of Lewis acid sites. The GaO+, due to the reduced electron density around the gallium ion, enhances the HZ catalyst’s ability to strongly accept electron pairs and act as a Lewis acid, making it more effective in plastic pyrolysis reaction requiring strong Lewis acid sites. Moreover, GaO+ ions can occupy cation exchange positions in the HZ, which are normally occupied by protons associated with Brönsted acid sites. When GaO+ ions occupy these positions, they displace protons, thereby reducing the density of Brönsted acid sites. Ga2O3 can interact with the surface hydroxyl groups in the zeolite framework. This interaction can neutralize Brönsted acid sites, leading to a further reduction in their density. Furthermore, Ga2O3 species may migrate into the HZ framework or surface, blocking access to Brönsted acid sites and thereby reducing their accessibility. 3.1.7 CO2-TPD analysis Fig. 7 provides the CO2-TPD profiles of various catalysts, including HZ, Ga-impregnated HZ, and reduction-oxidation treated GHZ with different Ga contents. Upon the introduction of gallium into HZ, a slight increase in the desorption peak temperature (from 210 to 220 °C) was observed, which indicates the increase of adsorption strength of CO2 on the active sites and the basicity on the catalyst surface. The increase of adsorption strength of CO2 by gallium-addition can allow the enhancement of catalytic activity. In the case of RO-GHZ(1) that was thermally treated under redox conditions, the area of CO2 desorption peak increased as compared to untreated GHZ(1) sample. This change is attributed to the significant increase of basic sites via the transformation from Ga2O3 nanoparticles to GaO+ ions, as confirmed in the TEM investigation. These basic sites are known to play a crucial role in dehydrogenation reactions, where they weaken the C–H bonds of hydrocarbons, promoting the formation of alkenes [42]. The formation of alkenes is particularly important as it facilitates subsequent chemical reactions, such as the Diels-Alder reaction, which directly contributes to the enhanced production of BTEX compounds. Furthermore, the increase in the desorption peak area for RO-GHZ(1) indicates that the catalyst possesses a high CO2 adsorption capacity, which could be advantageous in reactions involving CO2 or CO2-rich environments. This enhanced interaction with CO2 is expected to influence significantly the distribution of products during processes such as the pyrolysis of polypropylene (PP). Ultimately, these results underscore the importance of both gallium incorporation and reduction-oxidation treatment in optimizing catalyst properties for specific reactions, demonstrating their potential to improve catalytic performance and product selectivity. 3.1.8 TEM analysis By comparing the TEM images and EDS mappings in Figs. 8 . (a)–(f), which correspond to HZ, GHZ, R-GHZ(1), RO-GHZ(1), RO-GHZ(3), and RO-GHZ(5) catalysts, significant differences in the dispersion and size of gallium species can be observed. The TEM image of HZ shows the pristine zeolite framework. After the incorporation of Ga species, GHZ(1) exhibited several Ga2O3 particles with the average diameter of 10 nm, mostly at the external boundary of the zeolite particles. When this sample was reduced to R-GHZ(1) sample, Ga2O3 particles were converted to Ga2O, following reaction mechanism described in Eq. (5). However, the Ga2O species still remained as nanoparticles, as shown in Fig. 8, but the particle size was reduced somewhat. On the other hand, in the case of RO-GHZ(1) that was further treated under oxidation conditions, there were no specific Ga2O3 particles in the TEM and STEM images, but highly dispersed tiny spots were shown in the Ga-mapping EDS image. It is because that the Ga2O3 species was converted to Ga2O under reduction condition, and finally converted to GaO+ under oxidation condition following the reaction described in Eqs. (6) and (7), then transferred to cation exchange sites of the zeolite framework. In the case of catalyst samples with higher content of Ga, RO-GHZ(3) and RO-GHZ(5) still show large Ga2O3 nanoparticles in TEM and STEM images, even though these samples were treated by reduction and oxidation (see Fig. 8). This feature is attributed to the high content of Ga. Some portion of Ga2O3 was transformed to GaO+ that was migrated into the cation exchange sites of the zeolite, but the others still remained as Ga2O3 species even after the reduction-oxidation treatment. 3.1 Catalytic pyrolysis of PP in various reaction atmospheres 3.2.1 Effect of reaction atmosphere and catalyst type on the product yield The catalytic pyrolysis of PP was carried out at 600 °C using HZ and Ga-supported HZ catalysts (pristine and reduction-oxidation treated) under N2, CH4, and biogas atmospheres, respectively. The yield of the oil and gas phase product mixture is depicted in Fig. 9 . For HZ, the oil yield was 39.8 wt% in the N2 atmosphere, and it was increased to 43.8 wt% and 45.3 wt% with the addition of the CH4 and biogas conditions, respectively. This might be due to the difference in N2, CH4, and CO2 gases in their respective thermodynamic properties. The presence of methane moderates the reaction environment, reducing the formation of other radical reactions that can lead to undesirable by-products. Furthermore, methane contributes to a more controlled cracking process by acting as a mild reducing agent. This control may lead to higher selectivity towards desired intermediates like light olefins (ethylene, propylene) and paraffin. Notably, the presence of light olefins and paraffins improves the pyrolysis process by enhancing the hydrogen transfer reaction, which facilitates secondary cracking and improves the overall reaction kinetics. This leads to a relatively high selectivity of desired aromatic compounds. However, the comparative increase in the oil yield for the biogas might be corroborated by activation in the cracking of volatiles during the CO2-assisted pyrolysis of waste carbon resources [43–47]. Particularly, CO2 activation hinders the secondary/depolymerization reactions and favors the high oil yield by inducing a further cracking of volatiles. Additionally, the interaction of CO2 molecules and C–H, C–C bonds, and intermediate radicals induces the energy transfer to boost the oil yield, thereby reducing the gas yield. This well corroborates the recent study of Zhang et al. [48]. It is noteworthy that the oil yield was comparatively improved while using the Ga-loaded HZ GHZ(1) catalyst. Generally, the loading of Ga enhances the Lewis acidic sites over the surface of HZ and enhances the overall (Lewis/Brönsted) L/B acidic sites ratio. Notably, the Lewis acid sites arise from the ability of Ga3+ to accept electron pairs from Lewis bases. The oil yield was observed to be maximum (52 wt%) under N2. However, 48.2 wt% was calculated for CH4. For biogas, the oil yield was slightly increased to 49.8 wt% owing to the further facilitation of volatiles by CO2 and the catalyst’s surface-assisted reaction. The detection of similar oil yield (49.9 wt%) under CO2 might be corroborated with this explanation, which did not show any further improvement in oil yield due to the limitation of intermediates accessibility. According to the results of T@able 4 , in the presence of methane, there is a risk of increased coke formation. These deposits can block active sites and reduce catalyst activity. Carbon dioxide may not directly contribute to coke formation but can influence the overall carbon balance in the system. Methane and carbon dioxide can compete with reactants for adsorption sites on the catalyst. This competition can hinder the adsorption of the target molecules (e.g., plastic feedstock), reducing the catalyst’s effectiveness. Also, the interaction with these gases can affect the acidity of the ZSM-5 framework, potentially reducing the density or strength of Brönsted and Lewis acid sites. Generally, the reduction-oxidation of the Ga-loaded HZ (RO-GHZ) catalyst favors the transformation of Ga2O3 into GaO+ active species that may occupy the pore of the zeolite framework owing to their smaller ionic radii [32]. This allows numerous active sites of Ga to be located over the RO-GHZ’s surface. The BET analysis results corresponding to the higher surface area of RO-GHZ(1) might be directly correlated with this. Additionally, the results of XPS, and TEM analysis could also correlate with this observation. The reduction-oxidation not only affects the size of Ga active species (GaO+) but also enhances the overall L/B acidity to a high extent. This might be referring to Py-FT-IR analysis results. Notably, the oil yield was significantly improved while applying the RO-GHZ(1) catalyst. It was achieved to be 54.9 wt% under the N2-atmosphere. The oil yield was not affected much under CH4, and it was found to be 54.3 wt%. However, for CH4, the coke amount (T@able 4) was calculated to be high for the same RO-GHZ(1) in comparison to that of GHZ(1) and HZSM-5. This exhibited a high rate of reaction of PP’s active intermediates through the presence of Lewis/ Bronsted acidic sites, owing to their easy approach compared to other catalysts. Particularly, for RO-GHZ(1), the oil yield was increased under CO2 in comparison to GHZ(1) owing to a relatively high rate of reaction over RO-GHZ(1) and the promotion of PP’s cracking through CO2-activation. Therefore, the results exhibit that the reaction environment directly influences the pyrolysis behavior of PP owing to a variation in the reaction’s intermediates’ interaction with the catalyst’s properties. Coke detection analysis was also performed for all catalysts used, as provided in T@able 4. The coke was determined to be lesser under a biogas atmosphere. However, the maximum coke was detected under the CH4 atmosphere. This might be due to the partial activation of CH4 and the participation of produced methyl radicals with the present acidic sites of catalysts. Whereas CO2-assisted pyrolysis provides a favorable condition for the heterogeneous/homogeneous reaction of intermediates with CO2, leading to the augmentation of CO production. This CO generation usually becomes noticeable at ~600 °C [44], which could be distinguished from the CO2 effect of the Boudouard reaction (C + CO2 ↔ 2CO, 172 kJ/mol). Because Boudouard reaction/CO2 activation requires a high energy input, and it usually happens at >700 °C temperature [49]. Therefore, this shows a partial oxidation of carbon over the catalyst under the biogas atmosphere. This might be confirmed by the elevation of a marginal vol% of CO in the biogas atmosphere compared to others. The quantitative analysis of major target compounds BTEX was also evaluated for all oils. According to Fig. 10 , a 22.9 wt% BTEX was determined for HZ under the N2 atmosphere. However, it was increased to 25 wt% for the same HZ catalyst under the CH4 atmosphere and a 20.3 wt% BTEX yield was evaluated for biogas. This variation exhibits a significant alteration in the cracking behavior of the PP polymeric structure under the different reaction atmospheres. Particularly, HZSM-5 catalysts with strong acidic properties and high surface area favor the cracking of PP’s polymeric structure into respective olefins and facilitate their cyclization to a further transformation into aromatic hydrocarbons via the promotion of the dehydrogenation or elimination of H2 molecules. To understand this variation in BTEX production focuses on the generation of H2, CO, olefins, and alkanes. For HZSM-5, under biogas, the pyrolysis of PP exhibited a relatively higher vol% of butane together with a lesser proportion of H2 (T@able 5 ). Additionally, the proportion of ethene (C2H4) and butene (C4H8) were also detected to be relatively low, indicating a lesser probability of Diels Alder cyclization for producing the aromatics hydrocarbons. The calculated lesser ratio of C2H4/C2H6 and C3H6/C3H8 might also be correlated to the above explanation (T@able 6 ). In contrast, for CH4, the detection of a lesser proportion of butene (C4H8) and high H2 (T@able 5) indicates the promotion of aromatization reactions, such as cyclization and dehydrogenation, at a relatively high rate. This might also be referring to lesser C2H4/C2H6 and C3H6/C3H8 ratio (T@able 6). Amongst the BTEX, the yield of toluene was found to be comparatively higher under CH4. This might be due to the successful participation of the produced propene in cyclization and the promotion of alkylation of the benzene ring via the produced methyl radical, which is owing to an improvement in the cracking rate of PP’s structure. For GHZ(1), the BTEX yield was comparatively increased in comparison to the HZ catalyst. In particular, gallium, when it is incorporated into the HZ framework or deposited on its surface, often exists in oxidized states (such as Ga3+), which function as Lewis acid sites due to their ability to accept electron pairs. Moreover, when gallium is introduced into HZ, it can also interact with the existing Brönsted acid sites, which are typically associated with the protonated forms of the zeolite (Si-OH-Al groups). Gallium ions can replace these protons. This leads to an inclusive increase in L/B acidic sites and enhances the overall aromatization reaction. An increase in the dehydrogenation/H2 generation tendency of catalysts well confirms it. However, the larger size of Ga2O3 inhibits the pores and limits the overall activity of GHZ(1) catalysts. Interestingly, the BTEX yield was determined to be high at 28.5 wt% under the biogas atmosphere. However, the minimum BTEX yield (23.1 wt%) was obtained under CH4. Additionally, the overall trend of BTEX yield was determined as biogas > N2 > CH4 (Fig. 10). Particularly, For GHZ(1), the larger size of Ga2O3 enforces the overall reaction through the surface of the catalyst and limits the interaction of CH4 molecules with the surface properties of GHZ(1). The lowest yield of toluene (9.7 wt%), as well as the relatively low coke detection under CH4, could also relate to this explanation. In contrast, the CO2 proportion of biogas may activate the aromatization and enhance the overall yield of BTEX. Zhang et al. [47] suggested that CO2 works as a mild oxidizer and removes the excessive H2 by inducing the reverse water gas reaction. This enhances the rate of aromatization among the olefins. They reported the maximum BTEX yield over Ga/HZSM-5 catalyst under the CO2 compared to the N2 atmosphere. A similar observation for aromatic production was also reported by Zhou et al. [50]. Notably, the results of CO2-assisted pyrolysis of PP exhibited a significant increase in BTEX production to 32.7 wt% over the GHZ(1) catalyst. This further validates that CO2 promotes a deep thermal cracking of the PP polymeric structure, assisting the production of BTEX dominantly over the GHZ(1) catalyst. Particularly, under CO2, the comparatively lowest proportion of olefins indicates their significant consumption in the aromatization for the production of aromatics. According to the reported literature [51], the GaO+/HZ performs an excellent dehydrogenation reaction in contrast to that of Ga2O3/HZ. In general, this reduction-oxidation treatment of Ga favors the successful loading of GaO+ inside the pore and also regulates the overall L/B acidity of the catalyst. For RO-GHZ(1), a relatively higher 27.7 wt% BTEX yield was noticed under the N2 atmosphere compared to HZ and GHZ(1) catalysts. This BTEX yield showed a notable increase to 39.5 wt% under CH4 for the same RO-GHZ(1), indicating the activation of PP’s cracking and participation in the aromatization. The behavior of this RO-GHZ(1) catalyst was noticed to be opposite to that of GHZ(1). The smaller size of active GaO+ ions advocate the easy interaction of CH4 and PP’s breakage intermediate, and the relatively better thermodynamic properties assist in the formation of higher olefins via dehydrogenation. The generated H2 helps to retain the GaO+ state of the RO-GHZ(1) catalyst and assists in the cyclization/ aromatization reactions to enhance the BTEX formation. It is noteworthy that this BTEX production dropped remarkably under the biogas atmosphere. This shows a diverse impact of the CO2 proportion of biogas on aromatization reaction owing to partial oxidation of active GaO+ species. This might be well confirmed by the results of the CO2 atmosphere for the same RO-GHZ(1) catalysts, where the BTEX was further decreased to a minimum value of 21.2 wt%. This validates the adverse impact of CO2 on the catalytic properties of RO-GHZ(1), owing to its mild oxidizing properties. The lowering in selectivity of H2 (T@able 5) was also determined to be as CH4 > Biogas > N2 > CO2, which might be correlated with the aromatization/ dehydrogenation potential of RO-GHZ(1) catalyst. According to T@able 6, the lowest ratio of C2H4 alkene/C2H6 alkane of CH4 (1.8) exhibited a significant consumption of olefins to transform into aromatic/ benzene derivatives under the CH4. However, this ratio was found to be maximum at 2.28 for CO2-assisted pyrolysis of PP over RO-GHZ(1) catalyst. In summary, the loading of Ga over HZ exhibited a significant improvement in the dehydrogenation/aromatization tendency of the HZSM-5 catalyst. Additionally, the loading of Ga as GaO+ exhibited a remarkable impact on the BTEX yield under CH4. That might also be corroborated by high H2 vol% selectivity for the same. In contrast, the presence of Ga2O3 over HZ showed better BTEX results under the CO2. The gas analysis profile also validates the active participation of olefins and exhibits their respective consumption toward the BTEX production. Overall, the RO-GHZ(1) catalysts were found to be superior for the significant transformation of PP into valuable aromatic hydrocarbons under the CH4 atmosphere. A series of experiments were also designed to assess the impact of methane on the production of aromatics using the GHZ(1) and RO-GHZ(1) catalysts; the experiments were conducted under both CH4 and biogas atmosphere without the use of PP feedstock. The experimental results revealed that no condensable oil was produced under these conditions. Additionally, no significant change was observed in the gas profile after the reaction for the same GHZ(1) and RO-GHZ(1) catalysts. The findings suggest that the presence of methane helps steer the pyrolysis of PP toward the formation of short-chain olefins like ethylene, propylene, and other light alkanes, not forming the aromatics by itself. According to Lee et al. [19], the co-feeding of alkane on methane assists in dehydroaromatization by lowering the Gibbs free energy significantly. Therefore, the utilization of methane was advantageous in getting a high yield of BTEX from the pyrolysis of PP over RO-GHZ(1) catalyst. 3.2.2 Effect of Ga concentration The effect of Ga loading (0.5 wt%, 1 wt%, 3 wt%, and 5 wt%) was also examined under the CH4 and biogas atmosphere to enhance the selectivity of BTEX from the pyrolysis of PP. The catalytic performance of the RO-GHZ catalysts revealed a strong dependence on Ga concentration, which significantly influenced both oil and BTEX yields, as illustrated in Fig. 11 . Under the CH4 atmosphere, the oil yield was observed to be 50.3 and 54.3 wt% for the RO-GHZ(0.5) and RO-GHZ(1), respectively. A further increase in Ga to 3 wt% (GHZ(3) resulted in oil yield of 56.5 wt%, which remained constant even with the higher Ga loading of RO-GHZ(5). A similar trend in oil yield was observed under the biogas atmosphere, where the yield increased significantly from 52.0 wt% with RO-GHZ(0.5) to a maximum of 58.2 wt% with RO-GHZ(5). The comparatively higher oil yield under the biogas atmosphere can be attributed to the mitigating effect of CO2, which reduces coke formation and enhances the catalyst’s efficiency and stability during the pyrolysis process. According to Fig. 12 , the BTEX yield tended to decrease unlike the oil yield with increasing Ga loading due to reduced active site availability. When RO-GHZ(1) was used, the total BTEX yield increased compared to RO-GHZ(0.5) in both CH4 and biogas atmosphere, reflecting optimal dispersion of GaO+ species. However, the yield continued to decrease as gallium concentrations increased to 3 wt% and 5 wt% due to Ga aggregation. These results indicate that excessive Ga loading suppresses BTEX selectivity by reducing the presence of active GaO+ species. This result aligns with the observed BET surface area trends. The reduction in surface area with higher Ga loadings indicates a decrease in the dispersion of GaO+ species, reducing the number of accessible active sites and Brönsted acid sites required for effective aromatization. RO-GHZ(1), with its higher surface area, maintained better Ga dispersion, which enhanced BTEX selectivity compared to the more aggregated RO-GHZ(3) and RO-GHZ(5). These findings highlight that an appropriate ratio between Brönsted and Lewis acid sites is essential for maintaining high catalytic efficiency. 3.2.3 Effect of reduction-oxidation treatment of Ga/HZSM-5 To evaluate the catalytic activity of different Ga active sites, an additional catalyst, reduction-Ga/HZSM-5(1) (R-GHZ(1), which underwent only the reduction process, was introduced and tested under various atmospheric conditions (Fig. 13 ). Under N2 conditions (Fig. 13(a), the RO-GHZ catalyst exhibited the highest BTEX yield of 27.7 wt%, outperforming both GHZ (26.8 wt%) and R-GHZ (26.2 wt%). Similarly, in the CH4 atmosphere (Fig. 13(b), RO-GHZ demonstrated exceptional catalytic efficiency with a maximum BTEX yield of 39.6 wt%, significantly higher than R-GHZ (28.1 wt%) and GHZ (23.1 wt%). Methane activation appears to favor the RO-GHZ catalyst, potentially due to its enhanced ability to facilitate aromatization. However, under biogas conditions (Fig. 13(c), R-GHZ outperformed the other catalysts with a yield of 34.9 wt%, followed by RO-GHZ (31.2 wt%) and GHZ (28.5 wt%). The balanced composition of biogas may enhance the performance of R-GHZ due to its active sites promoting hydrocarbon transformation. Conversely, in the presence of CO2 (Fig. 13(d), GHZ was the most effective catalyst, yielding 32.6 wt% BTEX. However, R-GHZ and RO-GHZ produced 27.0 wt% and 21.0 wt%, respectively. These differences are caused by variations in the oxidation state of Ga and the composition of the C1 gas, which lead to differences in the catalytic activity. Under biogas conditions, while the Ga2O3 in the GHZ catalyst can be converted to Ga2O, this requires two steps: (1) an initial reduction reaction and (2) a subsequent reaction with CO2 to form GaO+. These two sequential reactions must occur, and if the CO2 concentration is insufficient, the likelihood of Ga2O reacting further is reduced. However, in the case of R-GHZ, which is already in the Ga2O state, CO2 can directly oxidize Ga2O, increasing the probability of forming GaO+ rapidly. However, under excess CO2 conditions, the Ga2O3 in GHZ reacts with the hydrogen produced during the reaction, becoming reduced to Ga2O. Subsequently, the high CO2 concentration provides an environment where Ga2O can be oxidized to GaO+, thereby enhancing the activity of GHZ. In contrast, R-GHZ and RO-GHZ appear to undergo further oxidation to Ga2O3 due to the excess CO2. This demonstrates that, compared to an N2 atmosphere, the GaO+ form is an active site that more effectively promotes the reaction of PP and CH4. As demonstrated by the TPR and XPS analysis, the reduction and oxidation processes lead to the formation of distinct Ga active sites, each with unique characteristics and catalytic properties. These active sites, which are influenced by the specific conditions of the reduction or oxidation process, exhibit significant differences in their activity. Furthermore, the performance of these Ga active sites is highly dependent on the presence of C1 gas and its composition. This suggests that the nature of the Ga active sites plays a crucial role in determining their catalytic behavior under varying atmospheric conditions, highlighting the importance of understanding and tailoring these active sites for specific reactions. 3.3 Overall reaction mechanism Ga/ZSM-5 can change into various active species (Ga2O, Ga+, GaO+, GaH2 +, etc.) through reduction and oxidation treatments. Qian et al. [52] investigated the aromatization of HDPE and PP using Ga-promoted zeolites with varying Ga loadings and pretreatment methods. Their study found that redox-treated Ga/Z5 generated stable GaO+ species, resulting in a 65% aromatic yield with 90% BTEX selectivity. Liu et al. [53] also demonstrated that the formation of GaO+ via reduction-oxidation treatment significantly enhances the conversion of light alkanes like propane into aromatics in Ga-modified HZSM-5. Rane et al. [54] studied the influence of different Ga species on alkane dehydrogenation and found that GaO+ exhibits superior C–H bond activation compared to Ga2O3 and GaH2 +, ultimately improving aromatic selectivity. These findings demonstrate that Ga-modified zeolites promote the formation of aromatic hydrocarbons in the plastic pyrolysis. In particular, the active site of GaO+ not only plays a crucial role in the aromatization during plastic pyrolysis but also enhances the reactivity of CH4 to proceed co-aromatization with light alkanes and alkenes [19,55]. From this perspective, to evaluate the intrinsic effect of Ga2O3 itself, we conducted experiments under a CH4 atmosphere using pure Ga2O3 without loading it onto ZSM-5. As a result, a wax-like product similar to that obtained under non-catalytic conditions was observed (S3). This finding indicates that Ga2O3 alone does not exhibit catalytic activity in the pyrolysis reaction and that its transformation into active sites occurs through interaction with ZSM-5 and H2-O2 treatment. Additionally, to assess the post-reaction state of the H2-O2 treated Ga/ZSM-5 catalyst (RO-GHZ(1), XPS analysis was performed on the catalyst used under CH4 atmosphere (S4). The results indicate that the spent catalyst exhibited GaO+ peak similar to the fresh catalyst, suggesting that the Ga active species did not change after the experiment. Furthermore, to confirm whether methane actually participates in the aromatic formation reaction, the reaction was conducted using 13CH4 isotopic gas, and the resulting oil products were analyzed using 13C-NMR (Fig. 14 ). When the 13CH4 was used as an atmospheric gas instead of 12CH4, peaks intensity for aromatic hydrocarbons became larger with similar intensity of aliphatic hydrocarbons. Especially, as shown in S5, the 13C peak area values of benzene and toluene, which account for the largest proportion among BTEX, increased by approximately 40% in the oil under a 13CH4 atmosphere compared to the oil under a 12CH4 atmosphere, while xylene also increased by 10%. This result means that 13CH4 species in atmospheric was involved in aromatic carbon compounds during the reaction. Strong peak intensity was observed at 128.36 and 129.09 ppm, corresponding to benzene and toluene, and the presence of 13C was also confirmed in the 20–40 ppm range, which primarily represents aliphatic hydrocarbons [56]. Liu et al. [57] confirmed that C1 incorporation occurred during co-aromatization of methane and propane by analyzing aromatic products obtained from a run with 13CH4, which showed significant 13C enrichment in the C6H6 +, C7H8 +, and C8H10 + fragments. Luzgin et al. [58] also monitored methane activation and co-aromatization with propane on Ga-modified zeolite BEA (573–823 K) using 13C solid-state NMR and GC-MS, confirming significant 13C incorporation into benzene and toluene. Anyway, it is certain that the methane added to the PP reactant is involved in the formation of aromatic compounds and increases the aromatics’ yield, as confirmed in this work. From these results, two possible pathways can be considered: (1) methane may have participated for the formation of aliphatic intermediates before ultimately converting into aromatic compounds, or (2) it may have been inserted into the previously formed aromatic hydrocarbons, which were produced during the process of PP pyrolysis. (1) Aliphatic hydrocarbon intermediate route Methane (CH4) is highly stable due to its strong C-H bonds, making its activation thermodynamically challenging. However, the co-feeding of light alkanes (e.g., ethane and propane) has been shown to reduce the thermodynamic barrier for methane activation and facilitate aromatic compound formation [19]. This mechanism leverages the synergistic effects of GaO+ sites on the catalyst and the co-reactants to activate methane and promote the aromatization reaction. GaO+ abstracts hydrogen from methane, generating reactive intermediates such as CH3• (methyl radicals) or surface-bound CH x species. This interaction weakens the C-H bonds in methane, creating conditions conducive to further reactions. CH4 + GaO+ → Ga−H + CH3• Then, the light alkanes and alkenes, introduced derived from pyrolysis of PP, interact with GaO+ to form reactive carbocations or radicals. C2H6 + GaO+ → Ga−H + C2H5• CH3• and C2H5• radicals combine to form larger alkanes (e.g., propane) and alkenes (e.g., ethylene), which serve as precursors for aromatic formation CH3• + C2H5• → C3H8 Larger hydrocarbons undergo cyclization on the Brönsted acid sites of the zeolite. GaO+ facilitates the removal of hydrogen atoms from cyclic intermediates, leading to the formation of stable aromatic compounds like benzene, toluene, and xylene. C6H12 → C6H10 → C6H6 + 2H2 The GaO+ sites are regenerated by releasing adsorbed hydrogen as molecular H2, maintaining the catalytic cycle Ga−H → GaO+ + H2 The fact that GaO+ serves as an active site with high performance in a CH4 environment is evidenced by experimental results involving the pyrolysis of polypropylene (PP) in various C1 atmospheres using different states of Ga species. (2) Methane insertion in aromatic hydrocarbon Aromatic hydrocarbons (such as benzene, toluene, or other aromatics) are already present in the reaction medium, possibly formed from plastic pyrolysis products or generated in earlier stages of the reaction. The methyl radical (CH3•) or methyl cation (CH3 +), produced from methane, inserts into the 12C aromatic ring (e.g., benzene or toluene). This insertion involves the methyl group attaching to the aromatic carbon atom, forming a methylated aromatic compound (e.g., 13C-benzene or 13C-toluene) [59]. To understand the further mechanistic cracking behavior of PP under the different reaction environments of N2, CO2, and CH4 over the HZ, Ga-loaded HZ catalyst, it is necessary to understand the composition of obtained oils. The GC-MS analysis results demonstrate a major proportion of BTEX, OMAHs (other mono aromatic hydrocarbons), PAHs (poly aromatic hydrocarbons), and olefins. This exhibited a prominent role of cyclization (Diels Alder reaction) and dehydrogenation reaction to transform the generated unsaturated olefins into valuable aromatic hydrocarbons. A marginal amount of paraffin was detected. Particularly, the Lewis acidic sites/their respective active forms over the zeolite catalysts significantly affect such a transformation. It is clear that catalytic pyrolysis initiates a further decomposition of thermally produced intermediates over the acidic sites of the catalyst [12,60], leading to the formation of short-chain olefins, for instance, 1-pentene, 1,3-pentadiene-2,4-dimethyl, 2,3-dimethyl-2-heptene, etc., as depicted in Fig. 15 . In contrast, thermal pyrolysis of the same plastic polymer predominantly yields long-chain hydrocarbons (C20–C30) due to random and uncontrolled fractionation [61,62]. These resulting olefins may diffuse into the pores of the catalyst, where they actively participate in cyclization, dehydrogenation, and hydrogen transfer reactions [51,63]. This process leads to their further conversion into mono-aromatic hydrocarbons, such as benzene, toluene, ethylbenzene, and xylenes (BTEX), along with alkyl derivatives of benzene. These monoaromatic hydrocarbons can further react with other olefins to form polyaromatic hydrocarbons, such as naphthalene derivatives. Additionally, alkyl isomerization can induce the formation of substituted benzene derivatives, like xylene and alkyl benzene. As illustrated in Fig. 15, the production of BTEX is primarily driven by Diels-Alder cyclization involving the olefinic hydrocarbons generated during the process. The GC-MS analysis identified the production of olefins like 1-pentene and 2-pentene. Additionally, gas analysis (T@able 6) revealed that propene was the major olefin and propane was the primary alkane. According to Fig. 15, 1-pentene undergoes β-scission at the acid sites of the catalyst, converting into 1,4-butadiene. This 1,4-butadiene then reacts with a dienophile, such as 1-propene, to form a cyclic adduct, which further transforms into aromatic hydrocarbon via dehydrogenation. The production of the high selectivity of toluene might be related to the high probability of the generation of such a diene and dienophile, owing to such a specific polymeric structure of PP. The formation of other aromatics, such as benzene and its derivative, might also be understood in the same way. According to the oil composition, for HZ, the BTEX production was obtained to be high, with a relatively lower proportion of PAHs under the CH4. This may be due to the activation of PP cracking by CH4 and the generation of a relatively high proportion of olefins via inducing a dehydrogenation reaction. For the GHZ(1) catalyst, the BTEX was observed to be high for CO2-assisted pyrolysis. This process involves partial activation of the water-gas shift reaction (CO2 + H2 → CO + H2O), which subsequently promotes methanation (CO + 3H2 → CH4 + H2O) [48]. The generated methane facilitates the production of alkanes, which are then converted into olefins through CO2-assisted dehydrogenation. These olefins undergo further transformation into aromatic hydrocarbons via cyclization and dehydrogenation. The relative lower selectivity of H2 (T@able 5) may corroborate this and might confirm the subsequent H2 consumption for the same reverse water shift reaction. The detection of only trace amounts of olefins suggests their effective conversion into aromatic hydrocarbons. Particularly, the presence of Ga2O3 over the GHZ(1) catalyst limits its activity toward dehydrogenation and influences the overall rate of aromatization. However, the relatively smaller size of GaO+ on the RO-GHZ(1) catalyst allows for easier diffusion into the pores of the zeolite framework. This assists in the dehydrogenation reaction, thereby promoting the conversion of alkanes into olefins more effectively. The high selectivity for BTEX and other aromatics can be attributed to the excellent catalytic activity of GaO+ compared to HZSM-5 and GHZ(1) catalysts, and it might be well related to the aforementioned explanation. Additionally, the presence of relatively high H2 favors retaining the oxidation state of Ga (GaO+) and maintains the catalyst activity toward the BTEX formation. 4 Conclusions The influence of various C1 gases, such as methane, carbon dioxide, and biogas (CH4 + CO2), exhibited significant diversity in the pyrolysis behavior of PP over the Ga-loaded HZSM-5 catalysts. Notably, the oil yield was increased by an order: HZ < GHZ(1) < RO-GHZ(1), owing to the excellent activity of RO-GHZ(1) compared to others. Particularly, the reduction-oxidation process reduces the size of the active form of Ga and settles it in the form of active GaO+ ions inside the pore of the zeolite framework. This demonstrated a relatively higher Lewis/Brönsted ratio of RO-GHZ(1) compared to GHZ(1). These outcomes were linked to the effective introduction of new Lewis acid sites upon HZSM-5 through GaO+ ions. The BTEX yield (39.5 wt%) exhibited a remarkable increase over the RO-GHZ(1) under the CH4 atmosphere. This BTEX yield dropped considerably on increasing the Ga-loading over the RO-GHZ under a similar CH4 atmosphere, owing to the lowering of the relative proportion of active GaO+ species. Moreover, a drop in BTEX was also observed for both biogas and CO2, owing to an adverse impact of CO2 on the catalyst properties of RO-GHZ(1). For the GHZ(1) catalyst, a maximum BTEX yield was obtained under CO2 conditions. Additionally, the CO2 and biogas-assisted reaction showed a lesser coke deposition over the surface of the catalyst because of partial oxidation of coke. The proposed mechanism well revealed the role of active GaO+ ion toward the BTEX production from the pyrolysis of PP and also validated the results of characterization. Overall, the study reveals the adequacy of sustainable C1 gases such as CO2 and CH4 toward producing valuable hydrocarbons BTEX from the pyrolysis of plastic wastes. coredata.dc:description: This study explores, for the first time, the influence of various C1 gases, such as methane (CH4), carbon dioxide (CO2), and biogas (CH4 + CO2), on catalytic pyrolysis of plastic waste (polypropylene) to evaluate their potential in producing aromatic hydrocarbons. Also, this study used the 0.5 wt%, 1 wt%, 3 wt%, and 5 wt% Ga-modified ZSM-5 catalyst and its reduction-oxidation processed catalysts owing to their promising catalytic properties. According to the results, the highest yield (39.5 wt%) of BTEX (benzene, toluene, xylene, and ethylbenzene) was achieved under CH4 over RO-GHZ(1) catalyst among all tested conditions. The reduction-oxidation process not only promotes a significant reduction of the Ga-size but also induces its diffusion inside the pore, compared to GHZ(1). This leads to the formation of highly active GaO+ ionic species, balancing the Lewis/Brönsted ratio, thereby accelerating the aromatization reaction. The effect of Ga loading on the RO-GHZ catalyst was also evaluated systematically, which showed a negative impact on the BTEX yield owing to the lowering in the concentration of active GaO+ species. A detailed catalyst characterization supports the experimental results well.

coredata.dc:title: Improvement in the production of aromatics from pyrolysis of plastic waste over Ga-modified ZSM-5 catalyst under C1-gas environment
